page.title: 01Streatlam To Kinnievie
page.content: This block, immediatly to the north of Barnard Castle, lacks any distinctive features common t its neighbouring blocks in Teesdale. The terrrain undulates gemtly. Predominantly grazing, there are small areas sown to kale, barley and potatoes, the former for animal feed. Approximately one third of the pasture is cropped as hat for winter feed. Winters can be very cold (-15c is common) due primarily to the high winds which are present intermitently throughour the year. Snow falls can average a dpeth of 3ft, but zero or 6ft in a season are not uncommon. Summers can be extremely pleasant, rarely becoming dry, yet with some sustained periods of fine weather allowing fine views across the dales. Principal occupations are farming, or working in Barnard Castle (often both).
